did.abstract: History professor at the University of Michigan (1956-1990) specializing in the early modern Atlantic economy, particularly the trade of tobacco and sugar between Europe and North America in the 17th and 18th centuries. Price served with the Army Air Force in China during World War II and twice served as chairman of the history department. Collection includes letters written during his military service, extensive correspondence with colleagues and scholars, material on the Francis Lowenheim case involving access to research material, and Price's research files and index cards detailing his research into colonial American and British merchants.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The main collection was donated in August 2012 (Donor No. 8204).

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Jacob M. Price papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Jacob Myron Price, a pioneer in quantitative methods of historical study, was born on November 8th, 1925, in Worcester, Massachusetts to Oscar and Agnes (Pike) Price. He entered Harvard in 1942 but joined the Air Force in 1944, working as a cryptographic technician then serving as a staff sergeant, and was sent to India until 1946. Following his service, he received his A.B., A.M., and Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1947, 1948, and 1954, respectively. He was also a member of Phi Beta Kappa. In 1954, he taught at Smith College before coming to the University of Michigan as an instructor in 1956. He became assistant professor in 1958, associate professor in 1961, and professor in 1964. Price served on every major committee within the Department of History, and served twice as its chair (1971-72, 1979-84). Price received the Distinguished Faculty Achievement Award in 1981 and was awarded Professor Emeritus status in 1991 after he retired in December 1990.

Price was known for his lectures on general European history, economic history, and modern British history. One of his early publications was Reading for Life: Developing the College Student's Lifetime Reading Interest (1959, reprinted in 1968). Nationally, he served on the board of editors of four scholarly journals and held a number of positions in the American Historical Association, including chairing the committee on quantitative data from 1967 to 1974 and co-editing Dimensions of the Past (1972). He also led the North American Conference on British Studies and its Midwest conference. He was a Fellow of the Royal Historical Society and of the British Academy and he was prominent in the Institute of Early American History and Culture at Williamsburg, and in the Economic History Association, which named him its president in 1987-88. He was also a Visiting Fellow at All Soul's College in Oxford.

He is best known for his work on trade between North America and Europe in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. His initial research concerned the Anglo-American development of the market for tobacco in Russia from 1676 to 1722. His interpretations, based on archival research in France, Britain, and the United States, made his publications landmarks in the understanding of capital formation, economic development, and the role of trade on the eve of the Industrial Revolution. His monumental study of the tobacco trade France and the Chesapeake (1973), was awarded both the University of Michigan Press Book Award and the Gilbert Chinard Prize of the Society for French Historical Studies. Later, he published the highly-influential Capital and Credit in British Overseas Trade (1980). He received fellowships from a variety of organizations, and was a corresponding member of the Massachusetts Historical Society and a fellow of the Royal Historical Society.

scopecontent.p: The Jacob Price Collection includes letters written during his military service, extensive correspondence with colleagues and scholars, material on the Francis Lowenheim case involving access to research material, and Price's research files and index cards detailing his research into colonial American and British merchants. The Collection is organized into six series: Correspondence, Dictionary of National Biography, Lowenheim Case, Personal, Research, and Index Cards.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Capital--Great Britain--History.
International economic relations--Great Britain--America.

controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Department of History.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (5.2 linear feet) contains correspondence written to Jacob Price, covering a variety of topics and from a variety of people. The original alphabetical filing order has been kept. Of particular note is the correspondence that Price wrote to his family while he was serving in the Air Force during World War II, letters from universities offering him positions, queries sent to Price regarding his research, and correspondence with various academic publishers.

did.unittitle: Answers to Queries (By State and City) 1951-1987
Historical Statistics of the United States 1996-2000
Kress Library of Business and Economics 1961-1979

scopecontent.p: The Dictionary of National Biography series (0.3 linear feet) contains the entries Price developed and submitted to be published in the Dictionary of National Biography on 18th century merchants involved in Anglo American trade. The files are organized alphabetically.

The Lowenheim Case series (0.2 linear feet) contains correspondence and reports relating to Price's friendship with historian Francis Lowenheim. The reports also show Price's support of Lowenheim in his dispute with the Roosevelt Library, the National Archives, and Harvard University Press and in his claim that documents needed in his research had been withheld from him.

The Personal series (0.3 linear feet) contains photographs, Price's personal diary from 1940, two awards, points from his will, records from his time as a faculty member at the University of Michigan, and various copies of his curriculum vitae.

The Research series (0.4 linear feet) contains reports from Price's various research projects. Also included are copies of reviews of Price's books and a copy of Price's paper Merchants and Planters: The Market Structure of the Colonial Chesapeake Reconsidered, which he wrote for the Conference on Activism, Rhetoric, and Research (CARR).

did.unittitle: Conference on Activism, Rhetoric, and Research Paper
Dimensions of the Past Book Reviews, 1973-1975

scopecontent.p: The Index Cards series (2 linear feet) is comprised of multiple boxes of index cards that Price wrote during his research. The boxes contain information on merchants, primarily organized alphabetically or geographically, that were of specific importance to Price's research into sugar or tobacco traders between America and the United Kingdom. The cards vary in degree of detail. Some contain biographical notes about the individual merchants, including their location and trade. Others contain information from other archival sources that have been compiled on the note cards.

The index cards, when taken together, provide a unique alphabetical directory of British and British American merchants trading to and from Britain and her American colonies during the 17th and 18th century. They also form a unique concordance to thousands of archival and printed sources documenting the lives and labors of these entrepreneurs. They would be of particular interest to scholars of business and economic history of the English-speaking Atlantic area.
